results.title: Hey, Kelly!
results.creator_credit: Sook-Yin Lee, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
During a friendly game of tag, Robert calls Kelly a racist name and a fight ensues. Both Kelly and Robert are given detention, and the Principal gives them a task where they must co-operate in order to achieve the desired end. It is through this co-operation and working together, that Robert realises that he has a great deal in common with Kelly, and that her “difference” is only “skin-deep”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sook-Yin Lee, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Playing Fair
results.creator_credit: Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A series of four dramas for 7-12 year olds intended to promote discussion on the issues of racism, respect and equality for children. Each episode revolves around a conflict where a child is taunted and discriminated against because they are a member of a minority group. The situations are credible and expose the impact of such behaviour on children.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Carol's mirror
results.creator_credit: Selwyn Jacob, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Playing Fair”.
Nobody wants to play Snow White in this year’s drama production except for Carol. Previous years she had to be content to play lesser roles or the wicked witch. However, for some of her classmates this is a problem, because Carol is not white. After much lively debate and creative thinking, Carol and her classmates find a solution and show that the problem is not Carol’s colour, but that the material itself and people’s expectations about Snow White are the real obstacle.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Selwyn Jacob, Wolf Koenig, Penny Ritco and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Hudson
results.creator_credit: Robert Heazlewood, Tasmanian Television and Corporate Communications
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Player Profile Series”.
Football statistics reveal that there has never been a finer spearhead in the history of Australian Rules Football than Peter Hudson. Historical highlights and interviews provide an insight into the game’s most potent offensive player and prolific goal kicking machine.

results.title: The Jim Stynes story: Dublin's Jim
results.creator_credit: David Barham and Australian Football Video
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Player Profile Series”.
In the early ‘80’s the Melbourne Football Club recruited an Irish schoolboy and by the start of the next decade, Jim Stynes had taken the art of ruck play to new levels and won the Brownlow medal.

results.title: Eat Art
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Play Printing”.
Backed by modern music, a group of painters silently act out movements as they create a mural piece by piece. The artwork takes form as the mural is placed on the wall until the completed artwork is seen to be food spread out on a checked tablecloth

results.title: Warlords II Deluxe for DOS
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case
results.brief_description: An updated version of the original game, Warlords II Deluxe adds higher resolution graphics, new terrain types, new scenarios and improved AI. It also allows for the creation of custom tile, army, and city sets for the map. The game is bundled with an improved version of the Warlords II Scenario Builder.

results.title: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Spectrum 48/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021
results.title_for_label: Asterix and the Magic Cauldron for Spectrum 48/128

Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/

Last accessed: 1/05/2021
description_for_label:
Asterix and the Magic Cauldron is a single player adventure arcade game. Players control Asterix through various maps, collecting keys for locked doors and fighting Romans and boars in search of seven pieces of Getafix’s Magic Cauldron. Fights take place on a separate screen mode. Stamina bars for each combatant appear on the side of the window. Defeating the combatant adds it to the food tally. If Asterix loses the fight, the window closes and he loses a life. The same system is used when fighting the Roman soldiers and when Asterix picks up objects.

Obelix will only follow if Asterix has a supply of hams which can be obtained from fighting boars. Asterix starts with five lives and one dose of Magic Potion per game, which can be activated by double tapping the fire button.

Original game developed by Beam Software for ZX Spectrum 48K, published in 1986 by Melbourne House.

Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/asterix-and-the-magic-cauldron/
